docs.lead_paragraph: Congress recently passed a law requiring drug companies to give Medicaid the same deep discounts they give other big customers. But instead of reducing Medicaid drug prices, many companies are now raising the prices that those other big customers must pay. For two decades, Medicaid, the Federal-state health program for poor people, has paid more for prescription drugs than other large buyers, like government and private health groups, which have negotiated discounts of 25 percent to 60 percent or more from the usual wholesale prices.

headline.main: MEDICAID IS DENIED DISCOUNTED DRUGS DESPITE A NEW LAW

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: War in the Gulf 6-8 U.S. troops fought Iraqi forces in sharp skirmishes on Saudi Arabia's northern borders in a day full of sometimes contradictory official statements on when the allies might start a ground offensive. Page 1 A high Iraqi official went to Moscow for talks that Soviet officials depict as possibly Iraq's last chance to avert a ground war. Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz made no comment on the war when he arrived. 7 Travelers say 10 Iraq aides were killed by protesters 7 Israel rules out Palestinian talks until war ends 7 Soldiers forced to go without liquor or drugs in the Saudi dessert are learning to live without. The Pentagon says that because of the Saudi prohibition on alcohol, it has noticed far fewer discipline problems among the troops. 1 Red Cross is frustrated on prisoners in Iraq 7 A new night-fighting technique is enabling American warplanes to destroy as many as 200 top-line Iraqi tanks a day, senior U.S. military officials said. 6 War notebook: This time, better deal for black servicemen? 6 President Bush was confronted by an antiwar campaigner in church, conferred with advisers about a ground offensive and said he hoped the war would be over soon during a visit to Kennebunkport, Me. 8 War was the focus of churchgoers in the New York metropolitan area as concern grew over the horror of hundreds of Iraqi civilians killed in an air raid and the prospect of a ground war's beginning soon. 25 Talk of ground war intensifies mood at antiwar protests 8 Washington Journal: By center of power, the center for protest 10 International 2-4 The slaying of a former contra chief in Nicaragua has the Government concerned about a surge in political tension. Officials said they would seek a rapid solution to the death of Enrique Bermudez, who was shot Saturday. 3 The death of a black man boiled alive in South Africa was ruled a "freak accident" and the two whites charged were found guilty of assault. Civil rights campaigners said the case pointed to inequality in the justice system. 2 High hopes for Uganda's President as a new-model African leader have been tempered by economic problems, scandals and an invasion into neighboing Rwanda. It has been a rocky period for Yoweri K. Museveni. 4 A legion of con men and smugglers is taxing Germany's ability to police its newly acquired eastern borders. The smugglers spill off of trains in cities like Dresden to trade clothes, liquor and pirated music tapes. 3 Florence Journal: Art with perfect past, indefinite future 4 National 10-12 A law aimed at lowering drug prices for Medicaid has had an unintended effect: Instead of giving Medicaid the same discount that is given to other big customers, drug companies are raising the prices they charge the other customers. 1 The run on the Bank of New England was worrisome, but panic eased when the F.D.I.C. took over. The lesson is that the run of today is far different from Depression-era runs that wiped out the life savings of millions. 1 Most forecasters take a rosy view, predicting that the recession will end by August and basing their optimism on past slumps. But other economists contend that the outcome of this recession is hard to forecast. 29 Nature's beauty minus the trouble of going into wild is the idea behind aplan at the edge of a national park in Utah: Tourists would see a film of the park on a huge screen, then stay overnight in a local motel. 1 Georgia is mired in recession. The state was once the centerpiece of the Southern economic boom, and Atlanta the capital of the New South. This year, the area will lose jobs for the first time since 1974. 10 Families of reservists are fighting another battle back home: making ends meet with less money. But the military points out that reservists knew they could be called to active duty at any time. 10 Childhood abuse: wider impact seen 11 Workers at arms plant end strike that riled town 11 Regional 25-28 New York's mental health system is at a crossroads symbolized by the proposed closing of Gowanda Psychiatric Center. Should the state continue spending on underused hospitals when there is no money to beef up community-based programs? 1 A suspect in a Hasidic girl's death was arrested. A Brooklyn man, 29, was charged with the murder of the 15-year-old girl, whose nude, charred body was found under the Williamsburg Bridge two months ago. 25 Ten people died in a Connecticut fire on Saturday. Fire officials in New Britain blamed an overheated extension cord for the blaze, which killed five young children. 27 Yale student slain on campus, an apparent robbery victim 26 Fare beaters are being put to work, scraping gum from subway station floors, scrubbing toilets or painting buildings. The idea is to turn offenders into examples to keep alive the idea that fare beating is a crime. 25 Private schools have hit hard times in New York City as teachers are being laid off, class sizes are rising and schools are merging. The problems include fewer students of high-school age and a shortage of money. 25 News analysis: The income-tax plan in Connecticut proposed by Governor Weicker may shatter a once-monolithic opposition to wage taxes, leaving in its place a field of half-enemies and half-friends. 26 Talks recessed as Daily News prepares offer 27 Business Digest 29 SportsMonday Autos: Earnhardt foiled again at Daytona 500 36 Baseball: Teams look for renewal 35 Maddox keeps up community ties 40 Pirates win doubleheader in arbitration 40 Harazin, Cashen to meet on Gooden, Viola contracts 40 Yankees regroup, trying to forget 1990 41 Basketball: Knicks rout Pistons 35 Ohio State beats Indiana in double overtime 42 Georgia Tech tops Arizona 42 Column: Berkow on hockey 39 Question Box 38 Figure Skating: Eldredge overtakes Bowman 37 Football: Cheerleading tryouts in London 39 Golf: O'Grady climbs back 36 Hockey: Anger lingers for Trottier 39 Outdoors: Skiing Vermont top to bottom 45 Tennis: Lendl tops Sampras 35 Obituaries 48 Richard England, choreographer Arts/Entertainment St. Ignatius Loyola's room 13 Changes in "American Psycho" 13 Insects in the movies 13 Music: Sting at the Beacon Theater 13 Violinist performs 18 Take Six at Carnegie Hall 19 The Waverly Consort 46 Dance: Elisa Monte company 18 David Parsons 18 Word and Image:"The MacGuffin" by Stanley Elkin 19 "Black Men: Uncertain Future" 46 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 22 The city and state are one A pride of Presidents Secret settlements Topics: Honorariums Letters 22 William Safire: Gorby forces G-Day 23 Anthony Lewis: Now the endgame 23 Peter Schweizer: Moscow's hidden gulf agenda 23 Tom Brokaw: Michael Creamer -- casualty of two wars 23 R. Kent Johns: The real Desert Storm 23

docs.lead_paragraph: Every day Lynn I. Miller looks through his office window at the Loyal Order of Moose and watches buses from big cities pull up across the street and disgorge drug addicts, alcoholics, people with AIDS and welfare families who need everything. "You see them getting off the buses and they don't know where to go," said Mr. Miller, administrator of the Moose lodge here, a chapter of the national fraternity.

headline.main: Town's Good Reputation Has Become Its Problem

byline.original: By MICHAEL deCOURCY HINDS, Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: A new Federal study has raised troubling questions about who will be helped by the AIDS drug AZT and how much. The study, conducted by the Department of Veterans Affairs, found that AZT, or azidothymidine, slows the development of symptoms in some people infected with the AIDS virus, yet people who took the drug before they had symptoms lived no longer than those who took it after they had symptoms.

headline.main: Federal Study Questions Ability Of AZT to Delay AIDS Symptoms
